I'll search Wikipedia for information about Apple Inc. and its founders.


Based on the Wikipedia article, Apple Inc. was founded on April 1, 1976, by three co-founders:

1. Steve Jobs
2. Steve Wozniak
3. Ronald Wayne

It's worth noting that Ronald Wayne sold his share of the company back to Jobs and Wozniak for $800 just twelve days after co-founding it. The company was then incorporated as Apple Computer, Inc. in 1977 with just Jobs and Wozniak as the remaining founders. Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak remained the most prominent figures in Apple's early history, with Wozniak designing the early Apple computers (including the Apple I and Apple II) and Jobs leading the business and marketing aspects of the company.

Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of corporate culture. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a Fortune 500 company. By the time of the "1984" television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.[258] According to a 2011 report in *Fortune*, this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.[259] In a 2017 interview, Wozniak credited watching *Star Trek* and attending *Star Trek* conventions in his youth as inspiration for co-founding Apple.[260]

Apple was founded as **Apple Computer Company** on April 1, 1976, by Steve Wozniak, Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated by Jobs and Wozniak as **Apple Computer, Inc.** in 1977. The company's second computer, the Apple II, became a best seller and one of the first mass-produced microcomputers. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. The company developed computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, including the 1984 original Macintosh, announced that year in a critically acclaimed advertisement called "1984". By 1985, the high cost of its products, and power struggles between executives, caused problems. Wozniak stepped back from Apple and pursued other ventures, while Jobs resigned and founded NeXT, taking some Apple employees with him.

**Apple Inc.** is an American multinational technology company headquartered in Cupertino, California. As of March 2023[update], Apple is the world's biggest company by market capitalization,[6] and with US$394.3 billion the largest technology company by 2022 revenue.[7] As of June 2022[update], Apple is the fourth-largest personal computer vendor by unit sales; the largest manufacturing company by revenue; and the second-largest mobile phone manufacturer in the world. It is considered one of the Big Five American information technology companies, alongside Alphabet (parent company of Google), Amazon, Meta, and Microsoft.

It has been referred to as "the most powerful company in the world"[10] and as one of the world's most valuable brands due to its market dominance, data collection, and technological advantages in the field of artificial intelligence.[11][12][13] Alongside Amazon, Apple Inc., Meta, and Microsoft, Google's parent company Alphabet Inc. is one of the five Big Tech companies.

Google's other ventures outside of Internet services and consumer electronics include quantum computing (Sycamore), self-driving cars (Waymo, formerly the Google Self-Driving Car Project), smart cities (Sidewalk Labs), and transformer models (Google Deepmind).[17]


Google and YouTube are the two most visited websites worldwide followed by Facebook and X (formerly known as Twitter). Google is also the largest search engine, mapping and navigation application, email provider, office suite, video sharing platform, photo and cloud storage provider, mobile operating system, web browser, ML framework, and AI virtual assistant provider in the world as measured by market share. On the list of most valuable brands, Google is ranked second by Forbes[18] and fourth by Interbrand.[19] It has received significant criticism involving issues such as privacy concerns, tax avoidance, censorship, search neutrality, antitrust and abuse of its monopoly position.

Google was founded on September 4, 1998, by American computer scientists Larry Page and Sergey Brin while they were PhD students at Stanford University in California. Together they own about 14% of its publicly listed shares and control 56% of its stockholder voting power through super-voting stock. The company went public via an initial public offering (IPO) in 2004. In 2015, Google was reorganized as a wholly owned subsidiary of Alphabet Inc. Google is Alphabet's largest subsidiary and is a holding company for Alphabet's internet properties and interests. Sundar Pichai was appointed CEO of Google on October 24, 2015, replacing Larry Page, who became the CEO of Alphabet. On December 3, 2019, Pichai also became the CEO of Alphabet.[14]

chat_history.content:
Based on the Wikipedia article, I can tell you about Google's founders:

Google was founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin on September 4, 1998, while they were PhD students at Stanford University in California. Here are some key points about the founders:

1. Larry Page and Sergey Brin together owned about 14% of Google's publicly listed shares and controlled 56% of its stockholder voting power through super-voting stock.

2. Initially, both founders had active roles in the company:
- Larry Page served as CEO before stepping down
- Sergey Brin served as President

3. The company structure changed over time:
- In 2015, Google was reorganized as a subsidiary of the newly created Alphabet Inc.
- Sundar Pichai replaced Larry Page as CEO of Google on October 24, 2015
- In December 2019, Pichai also became CEO of Alphabet

Both Page and Brin are now listed as "Former" executives in the company structure, though they maintain significant ownership stakes in the company. They started Google from humble beginnings at Stanford University and built it into one of the world's most valuable and influential technology companies.

Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of corporate culture. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a Fortune 500 company. By the time of the "1984" television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.[258] According to a 2011 report in *Fortune*, this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.[259] In a 2017 interview, Wozniak credited watching *Star Trek* and attending *Star Trek* conventions in his youth as inspiration for co-founding Apple.[260]

Apple was founded as **Apple Computer Company** on April 1, 1976, by Steve Wozniak, Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated by Jobs and Wozniak as **Apple Computer, Inc.** in 1977. The company's second computer, the Apple II, became a best seller and one of the first mass-produced microcomputers. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. The company developed computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, including the 1984 original Macintosh, announced that year in a critically acclaimed advertisement called "1984". By 1985, the high cost of its products, and power struggles between executives, caused problems. Wozniak stepped back from Apple and pursued other ventures, while Jobs resigned and founded NeXT, taking some Apple employees with him.

Nonetheless, it has maintained a reputation for fostering individuality and excellence that reliably attracts talented workers, particularly after Jobs returned. Numerous Apple employees have stated that projects without Jobs's involvement often took longer than others.[261]


The Apple Fellows program awards employees for extraordinary technical or leadership contributions to personal computing. Recipients include Bill Atkinson,[262] Steve Capps,[263] Rod Holt,[262] Alan Kay,[264][265] Guy Kawasaki,[264][266] Al Alcorn,[267] Don Norman,[264] Rich Page,[262] Steve Wozniak,[262] and Phil Schiller.[268]

Microsoft was founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen on April 4, 1975, to develop and sell BASIC interpreters for the Altair 8800. It rose to dominate the personal computer operating system market with MS-DOS in the mid-1980s, followed by Windows. The company's 1986 initial public offering (IPO) and subsequent rise in its share price created three billionaires and an estimated 12,000 millionaires among Microsoft employees. Since the 1990s, it has increasingly diversified from the operating system market and has made several corporate acquisitions, the largest being the acquisition of Activision Blizzard for $68.7 billion in October 2023,[3] followed by its acquisition of LinkedIn for $26.2 billion in December 2016,[4] and its acquisition of Skype Technologies for $8.5 billion in May 2011.[5]

**Microsoft Corporation** is an American multinational technology corporation headquartered in Redmond, Washington. Microsoft's best-known software products are the Windows line of operating systems, the Microsoft 365 suite of productivity applications, and the Edge web browser. Its flagship hardware products are the Xbox video game consoles and the Microsoft Surface lineup of touchscreen personal computers. Microsoft ranked No. 14 in the 2022 Fortune 500 rankings of the largest United States corporations by total revenue;[2] it was the world's largest software maker by revenue as of 2022. It is considered one of the Big Five American information technology companies, alongside Alphabet (parent company of Google), Amazon, Apple, and Meta.

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Based on the Wikipedia search results, I can tell you that Microsoft was founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen on April 4, 1975, in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The company was initially created to develop and sell BASIC interpreters for the Altair 8800 computer. Gates and Allen went on to build Microsoft into one of the world's largest technology companies, known particularly for its Windows operating system and Microsoft 365 (formerly Office) suite of productivity applications.

Some key points about the founders:

1. Bill Gates:
- Co-founder of Microsoft
- Served as CEO until 2000
- Was chairman of the board until 2014
- Currently serves as a technical advisor to the company
- Known for his philanthropic work through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation

2. Paul Allen:
- Co-founder of Microsoft
- Left his full-time position at Microsoft in 1983 due to health reasons (Hodgkin's lymphoma)
- Remained on the board of directors until 2000
- Passed away in 2018
- Was also known for his ownership of the Seattle Seahawks and various other business ventures

The partnership between Gates and Allen began when they were students at Lakeside School in Seattle, where they first started programming together. Their creation of Microsoft would go on to revolutionize personal computing and make both men billionaires. The company's 1986 IPO created three billionaires and an estimated 12,000 millionaires among Microsoft employees.

Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of corporate culture. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a Fortune 500 company. By the time of the "1984" television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.[258] According to a 2011 report in *Fortune*, this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.[259] In a 2017 interview, Wozniak credited watching *Star Trek* and attending *Star Trek* conventions in his youth as inspiration for co-founding Apple.[260]

Apple was founded as **Apple Computer Company** on April 1, 1976, by Steve Wozniak, Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated by Jobs and Wozniak as **Apple Computer, Inc.** in 1977. The company's second computer, the Apple II, became a best seller and one of the first mass-produced microcomputers. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. The company developed computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, including the 1984 original Macintosh, announced that year in a critically acclaimed advertisement called "1984". By 1985, the high cost of its products, and power struggles between executives, caused problems. Wozniak stepped back from Apple and pursued other ventures, while Jobs resigned and founded NeXT, taking some Apple employees with him.

chat_history.content:
Based on the Wikipedia article, Amazon was founded by Jeff Bezos on July 5, 1994. He started the company from his garage in Bellevue, Washington. Initially, it was called Cadabra, Inc. (1994-1995) before becoming Amazon.com, Inc. Jeff Bezos is the sole founder of Amazon - there were no co-founders.

Some key points about the founding:
1. Founder: Jeff Bezos
2. Founded: July 5, 1994
3. Original location: Bellevue, Washington (in Bezos's garage)
4. Original name: Cadabra, Inc. (1994-1995)
5. Initial business: Online marketplace for books, before expanding into "The Everything Store" selling multiple product categories

![](image)Universities with the most alumni at Apple
Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of corporate culture. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a Fortune 500 company. By the time of the "1984" television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.[258] According to a 2011 report in *Fortune*, this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.[259] In a 2017 interview, Wozniak credited watching *Star Trek* and attending *Star Trek* conventions in his youth as inspiration for co-founding Apple.[260]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Apple was founded as **Apple Computer Company** on April 1, 1976, by Steve Wozniak, Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated by Jobs and Wozniak as **Apple Computer, Inc.** in 1977. The company's second computer, the Apple II, became a best seller and one of the first mass-produced microcomputers. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. The company developed computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, including the 1984 original Macintosh, announced that year in a critically acclaimed advertisement called "1984". By 1985, the high cost of its products, and power struggles between executives, caused problems. Wozniak stepped back from Apple and pursued other ventures, while Jobs resigned and founded NeXT, taking some Apple employees with him.

Apple Computer, Inc. was incorporated on January 3, 1977,[20][21] without Wayne, who had left and sold his share of the company back to Jobs and Wozniak for $800 only twelve days after having co-founded it.[22] Multimillionaire Mike Markkula provided essential business expertise and funding of $250,000 (equivalent to $1,257,000 in 2023) to Jobs and Wozniak during the incorporation of Apple.[23] During the first five years of operations, revenues grew exponentially, doubling about every four months. Between September 1977 and September 1980, yearly sales grew from $775,000 to $118 million, an average annual growth rate of 533%.[24]

![](image)In 1976, Steve Jobs co-founded Apple in his parents' home on Crist Drive in Los Altos, California.[9] Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak called the popular belief that the company was founded in the garage "a bit of a myth".[10] They moved some operations to the garage when the bedroom became too crowded.[11]
![](image)The Apple I is Apple's first product, designed by Steve Wozniak and sold as an assembled circuit board without basic features such as a keyboard, monitor, and case. This unit received an aftermarket keyboard and a wooden case.
![](image)The Apple II Plus was introduced in 1979, designed primarily by Wozniak.

### Branding[edit]


![](image)The first official logo of Apple Inc. was used from 1977 to 1998.[194]
According to Steve Jobs, the company's name was inspired by his visit to an apple farm while on a fruitarian diet. Jobs thought the name "Apple" was "fun, spirited and not intimidating".[195] Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak were fans of the Beatles,[196] but Apple Inc. had name and logo trademark issues with Apple Corps Ltd., a multimedia company started by the Beatles in 1968. This resulted in a series of lawsuits and tension between the two companies. These issues ended with the settling of their lawsuit in 2007.[197]


</fragment>
<fragment>

As the company has grown and been led by a series of differently opinionated chief executives, it has arguably lost some of its original character. Nonetheless, it has maintained a reputation for fostering individuality and excellence that reliably attracts talented workers, particularly after Jobs returned. Numerous Apple employees have stated that projects without Jobs's involvement often took longer than others.[261]


The Apple Fellows program awards employees for extraordinary technical or leadership contributions to personal computing. Recipients include Bill Atkinson,[262] Steve Capps,[263] Rod Holt,[262] Alan Kay,[264][265] Guy Kawasaki,[264][266] Al Alcorn,[267] Don Norman,[264] Rich Page,[262] Steve Wozniak,[262] and Phil Schiller.[268]

**McDonald's Corporation** is an American multinational fast food chain, founded in 1940 as a restaurant operated by Richard and Maurice McDonald, in San Bernardino, California, United States. They rechristened their business as a hamburger stand, and later turned the company into a franchise, with the Golden Arches logo being introduced in 1953 at a location in Phoenix, Arizona. In 1955, Ray Kroc, a businessman, joined the company as a franchise agent and proceeded to purchase the chain from the McDonald brothers. McDonald's previous headquarters was based in Oak Brook, Illinois, but the company moved its global headquarters to Chicago in June 2018.[9][10][11][12] McDonald's is also a real estate company through its ownership of around 70% of restaurant buildings and 45% of the underlying land (which it leases to its franchisees).[13][14]

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with key information about McDonald's:

McDonald's is an American multinational fast food chain that was founded in 1940 by Richard and Maurice McDonald in San Bernardino, California. Here are some key points:

1. History:
- Started as a restaurant by the McDonald brothers in 1940
- Transformed into a hamburger stand and later a franchise
- The Golden Arches logo was introduced in 1953 in Phoenix, Arizona
- Ray Kroc joined as a franchise agent in 1955 and later purchased the chain from the McDonald brothers

2. Corporate Information:
- Current headquarters: Chicago, Illinois (moved from Oak Brook in 2018)
- Company type: Public company (NYSE: MCD)
- Number of locations: 40,031 restaurants (as of 2021)
- Operating in 119+ countries worldwide

3. Business Model:
- McDonald's is both a fast food chain and a real estate company
- Owns approximately 70% of restaurant buildings and 45% of the underlying land
- Leases these properties to franchisees

4. Key Products:
- Hamburgers
- Chicken
- French fries
- Soft drinks
- Soft serves
- Shakes
- Salads
- Desserts
- Breakfast items
- Coffee
- Wraps

5. Leadership:
- Current leadership includes:
  - Enrique Hernandez Jr. (chairman)
  - Chris Kempczinski (president & CEO)

6. Financial Performance:
- Revenue: US$23.223 billion (2021)

The company has grown from a single restaurant to one of the world's largest fast-food chains and most recognizable brands, known for its Golden Arches logo and standardized fast-food menu items served across the globe.

OCLC 971131326.; McCracken, Harry (April 1, 2016). "Apple's sales grew 150x between 1977–1980". *Fast Company*. Archived from the original on May 25, 2017. Retrieved May 2, 2017.

<fragment>

Apple was founded as **Apple Computer Company** on April 1, 1976, by Steve Wozniak, Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated by Jobs and Wozniak as **Apple Computer, Inc.** in 1977. The company's second computer, the Apple II, became a best seller and one of the first mass-produced microcomputers. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. The company developed computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, including the 1984 original Macintosh, announced that year in a critically acclaimed advertisement called "1984". By 1985, the high cost of its products, and power struggles between executives, caused problems. Wozniak stepped back from Apple and pursued other ventures, while Jobs resigned and founded NeXT, taking some Apple employees with him.

Apple Computer, Inc. was incorporated on January 3, 1977,[20][21] without Wayne, who had left and sold his share of the company back to Jobs and Wozniak for $800 only twelve days after having co-founded it.[22] Multimillionaire Mike Markkula provided essential business expertise and funding of $250,000 (equivalent to $1,257,000 in 2023) to Jobs and Wozniak during the incorporation of Apple.[23] During the first five years of operations, revenues grew exponentially, doubling about every four months. Between September 1977 and September 1980, yearly sales grew from $775,000 to $118 million, an average annual growth rate of 533%.[24]


</fragment>
<fragment>

![](image)Co-founder Steve Wozniak and engineer Andy Hertzfeld attended the Apple User Group Connection club in 1985.
![](image)Universities with the most alumni at Apple
Apple is one of several highly successful companies founded in the 1970s that bucked the traditional notions of corporate culture. Jobs often walked around the office barefoot even after Apple became a Fortune 500 company. By the time of the "1984" television advertisement, Apple's informal culture had become a key trait that differentiated it from its competitors.[258] According to a 2011 report in *Fortune*, this has resulted in a corporate culture more akin to a startup rather than a multinational corporation.[259] In a 2017 interview, Wozniak credited watching *Star Trek* and attending *Star Trek* conventions in his youth as inspiration for co-founding Apple.[260]


</fragment>
<fragment>
![](image)In 1976, Steve Jobs co-founded Apple in his parents' home on Crist Drive in Los Altos, California.[9] Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak called the popular belief that the company was founded in the garage "a bit of a myth".[10] They moved some operations to the garage when the bedroom became too crowded.[11]
![](image)The Apple I is Apple's first product, designed by Steve Wozniak and sold as an assembled circuit board without basic features such as a keyboard, monitor, and case. This unit received an aftermarket keyboard and a wooden case.
![](image)The Apple II Plus was introduced in 1979, designed primarily by Wozniak.

Apple Computer Company was founded on April 1, 1976, by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne as a partnership.[9][12] The company's first product was the Apple I, a computer designed and hand-built entirely by Wozniak.[13] To finance its creation, Jobs sold his Volkswagen Bus, and Wozniak sold his HP-65 calculator.[14]: 57 Neither received the full selling price but in total earned $1,300 (equivalent to $7,000 in 2023). Wozniak debuted the first prototype Apple I at the Homebrew Computer Club in July 1976.[15] The Apple I was sold as a motherboard with CPU, RAM, and basic textual-video chips—a base kit concept which would not yet be marketed as a complete personal computer.[16] It went on sale soon after debut for $666.66 (equivalent to $3,600 in 2023).[17][18]: 180 Wozniak later said he was unaware of the coincidental mark of the beast in the number 666, and that he came up with the price because he liked "repeating digits".[19]

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Based on the Wikipedia article, Apple Inc. was founded on April 1, 1976, by three co-founders:

1. Steve Jobs
2. Steve Wozniak
3. Ronald Wayne

It's worth noting that Ronald Wayne sold his share of the company back to Jobs and Wozniak for $800 just twelve days after co-founding it. The company was then incorporated as Apple Computer, Inc. in 1977 with just Jobs and Wozniak as the remaining founders. Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak remained the most prominent figures in Apple's early history, with Wozniak designing the early Apple computers (including the Apple I and Apple II) and Jobs leading the business and marketing aspects of the company.
